column1: Have there been anymore confirmed cases?
Not yet..... but anticipated,Borders closing here 23rd midnight
Forgot to addThis includes airspace Essential supplies allowed in Prices of essential food stocks for Gambians already escalating
First death from CV19 in Gambia reported today. RIP.
geraintw37, RIP? this man crossed the border into TG and may have infected many people - he is a preacher so how many has be blessed with this virus.Edited: 6:07 am, March 23, 2020
Yet the mosques are still open.
Couldn’t believe my local mosque this morning still calling out for prayer, they should be directed to call and instruct people to stay home 5 time’s a day if necessary!
The person who died was a preacher of the Ahmadiyyasect who had returned to TG from Senegal. Wonder how many he infected?
A lot of people are taking this virus seriously. Kairaba Ave,kotu and Kololi very quiet. Not the normal amount of traffic for the time of day

3rd Case today! https:/…

Varying reports here,some peeps I speak to in the medical profession tell me it's well here the problem is the Gambians will just think it's a fresh cold,loads of grocerys from Algyhage and Kairaba Ave super store so it's isolation time.
Sadly we have idiots congregating to go to the High Commission to vent their spleens. Not a face mask in sight, social distancing non existent - thank you members of the Gambia Tourism Forum
Latest updated data link:https:/…Edited: 10:06 am, March 25, 2020
Followed by:https:/…
Thanks interesting reading!
Now getting very close to home - case confirmed, Nurse at Brikama Hospital
Get your head around these stats if you can!https://www.ft.com/coronavirus-latest
Where did you see the report about a nurse at Brikama? Can't see it mentioned in any official reports.
https://pbs.twimg.com/media/ET-lbsRXYAk2Anw…This only shows the 3 cases previously reported plus the suspected one of the companion to the preacher.

Face masks don't do much unless they're FFP3 spec and they fit the face properly. Much more effective is staying 2m apart and regular/thorough handwashing with hot water and soap. We're approaching 1000 deaths in the UK now and most people have started to take it seriously and behave properly.

Something I heard on The World Service BBC: Where you widely see people in Hong Kong or elsewhere in Asia wearing face masks its because, there, people wear them to protect other people. In Europe and certainly in UK we think we wear them to protect ourselves. (No matter whether they are any use). A difference in the culture and attitude worth mulling over?Edited: 8:14 am, March 27, 2020

Many apologies for not getting back sooner. The ppst was based on a couple of reports later found to have come from a nurse at Brikama Hospital. This report was subsequently found to be totally incorrect and said nurse carpeted.Again my apologies as hate posting erroneous information
Facemasks would be great here, may stop them spitting.
True Easytime, I had to explain to someone yesterday not to spit because someone could walk on it and pick up the virus and bring it into the house. Nice bloke but....
As far as I know there have no been confirmed reports of cases in my area.
#26 Thara. Good news, but in Epsom, or a place in The Gambia? Its the Gambia travel forum!
In all honesty no-one has any idea what is happening here at the moment - we are still in the incubation period.I do believe this is the calm before the storm but really do hope I am wrong

Are all hotels and restaurants closed now or is it optional ?

Fourth case confirmed Sunday 29thCrasivo, like everything here, some closed, some operating because they are looking after tourists who could not get out before the airport closure. A repatriation flight left yesterday with Dutch and Germans stuck here. Still no news what will happen with Bits who are still here who wish to leave,Edited: 4:09 am, March 30, 2020
This page is regularly updated with the info:https:/…

Here is the official WHO site for Covid-19https:/…novel-coronavirus-2019Once you are on the main page, you should look at the latest report. As I type, it is report number 70 as follows:https:/…situation-reportsBe advised. This is the WHO official site and is updated daily.Edited: 9:19 am, March 31, 2020

Interesting that the WHO waited until March 12 to declare corona virus a pandemic, when it was plain for all to see by then. Whereas the NHS England declared it the highest level 4 emergency in mid January. I take the updates and figures from WHO with a pinch of salt.Edited: 1:35 pm, March 31, 2020

Post 34. It is irrelevant that it was plain to see long before they declared it a pandemic. It was in many other countries and recognized as such by them before 11th MARCH.The link below describes the thinking behind the wording calling it a Pandemic.Epidemic Vs. Pandemic: What Exactly Is the Difference?The worldwide coronavirus outbreak has officially been declared a pandemic, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced March 11 during a media briefing. According to WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, PhD, the decision to classify COVID-19 as a pandemic was not easy but resulted from concern for "the alarming levels of spread and severity, and by the alarming levels of inaction."https:/…epidemic-vs-pandemicI would rather use the data and the figures produced by the WHO as the most reliable because they have no affiliation with any particular country, and use the data from 194 different countries.Their site explains:https://www.who.int/features/qa/73/en/Edited: 6:23 pm, March 31, 2020

China are large contributors to WHO which is why they ignored research from Taiwan which proved transmission from person to person and not only animal to person as the Chinese claimed initially. WHO are just as institutionally corrupt as the UN and world bank.

Perhaps you do not understand that the data and figures published by WHO are all provided by individual countries and only collated by WHO. They do not verify the information provided. China as a permanant member of the UN security council has a history of vetoing votes that are at odds with it's interests. They do the same at WHO which is why Taiwan is refused membership.

BertYes, I do appreciate everything you said and I completely understand. I have been around the world a little, and at 77 years of age, have many life experiences and traveled the world since 1961. Even visiting zones where dangerous viruses are prevalent. What I was trying to say to you after your statement of:"I take the updates and figures from WHO with a pinch of salt."Was, that it was not the WHO figures we see on the WHO site, but the figures submitted to the WHO or gleaned from the countries (194) to keep the world up to speed on the numbers. These figures are very often distorted by local recording, especially in China. Even the figures sent in by the UK are not seen by most as reliable, because of the testing or not of people who might or might not have the virus. China has a veto.....Don't I know it! But.....they are not in a position to VETO what the WHO send out as data or figures, because they have already signed up to it.So to recap. I was taking issue with your statement of "I take the updates and figures from WHO with a pinch of salt." when it was individual countries data collated by the WHO and posted for all to see.If you do take the information promulgated with a pinch of salt, please advised us where you can get better data that we might find more reliable.Edited: 6:00 am, April 01, 2020
WHO got the numbers badly wrong on Ebola and their modelling was way off the mark. So pinch of salt is what I take with all statistics and damn lies in this crisis.
Bert.Good for you. Your choice.Edited: 6:13 am, April 01, 2020

I had been urging the people in my compound (Bakau) to stay at home and if essential to go outside to practise social distancing, and no visitors inside. Now I hear one boy is going outside to his 'shop'. Back to normal .... As obviously I'm not there I have no 'feeling' for how it is there, or the current advice. It's double difficult for Gambians not to socialise, to walk around. Its in the blood.
I read groups of no more than 5 for attya,crazy.
Still no further notified cases.The Gambians do not believe this is real and many going about business as situation normal.Their ignorance will kill them.
Hi !Your Compound in Bakau, is that your Freehold Land as a foreigner ?Edited: 8:54 am, April 05, 2020
From what I know there are no freeholds in TG. There are State leases, and Customary leases. I'm no lawyer; for any deeper info its best to ask one. In TG, preferably one that hasn't got one to sell!
Sorry Stephen, there are. Friend of mine has freehold land, mine is leasedEdited: 2:07 pm, April 06, 2020

Hi Peter. You may well be right. Or your friend thinks he has, as was told what they wanted him to hear, and him to believe. Its Gambian dealing and sales. You know that. Caveat Emptor! Read the notes ...https:/…

Or does it matter! Not freehold as understood in the UK but so long as your friend is happy in his lifetime and doesn't get kicked off, its terminology, semantics, and does it matter? The usual issue in TG is if the seller never owned it to sell it in the first place and the Alkalo was in cahoots .... It has been known!

Bernhard d ; This post is about the Coronavirus outbreak and most certainly not about freehold or leasehold land. If you want to ask about those issues why don't you start your own question instead of highjacking this one ?Perhaps now we can return to the original question thank you.Edited: 7:45 pm, April 06, 2020
To bring it back on track, still no further reported cases as of 06-04-20
Thanks Easytime

Locally some people believe the 3 at MRC had been deliberately faking it and that the marabout had died of something else or he would have infected many people and such cases haven't surfaced. The country is incredibly fortunate so far if true.
Pleased to see the theories coming out of people who have heard from a friend of a friend of the cleaner who washed the car of the driver who took them to MRC.

You yourself had to correct something you'd heard. Case confirmed, you wrote - nurse at Brikama hospital" #17. It comes to us all! And I've just noticed #20 from KRD re the companion of the preacher, I didn't know that. Fact, or false? We do our best to be correct, I'm sure.Edited: 5:18 pm, April 07, 2020
Here is the reference to the companion of the preacher in the report dated 17th March.https://www.dropbox.com/s/mqjo5c3kk4n5j4d/null.pdf.pdf?dl=0It is from a reliable source!
not sure whether the link copied well. https:/…
And here is the one which mentions the companion of Case 3 - the preacher - as a suspected case.https:/…

Many do not have Dropbox so cannot access the post. Some families in the Bundung area actually left as soon as this Preacher was confirmed with Covid 19.Still no more confirmed cases, we are living in the calm before the storm here.

I don't think you need Dropbox. Just click and it opens the link to the Ministry of Health and WHO daily reportToday, once again, 22 tests all negative and no more new cases.. Crossing fingers we may be lucky - as we were with the Ebola.
No it doesn't, you have to sign in.
The same information is available direct on the WHO site
09-04-2020, still no new cases reported as of 0730

Easyltime your post #63How many tests have been carried out? Not trying to trip you up, it is just that if there is no testing being carried out, then reported cases are meaningless. Not just in TG, but worldwide.

Frithwood, I can only go on what is posted here on Ministry site. They are only testing those who show up with symptoms. Lets face it, some could have already been buried who had the virus because so few checks are carried out here when someone dies.
Post #65I agree with your post entirely. So along with many poor countries, the statement of no new reported cases holds true.

I agree also; the dilemma however is that once this is all over, at what point will we in the UK trust The Gambia enough to return for our holidays?Unless we can develop a vaccine that is readily available from a Travel Clinic, then every holiday is a risk.

As likely TG will require a certificate of immunity from each of us! Most of us if not all will have had Covid-19 by then and most should be fit enough to travel - if we're not completely broke and there aren't Exchange Controls in place, say £40 per person max! It has happened!Can you afford a Julbrew could become a reasonable question!
There is no more Julbrew!The brewery has been closed down.https:/…
And here is the direct link to the MOH and WHO daily situation reports page -http://www.moh.gov.gm/covid-19-report/

Not many testing kits by the sounds of it .The QTV news is more concerned about the donation and sanitary gifts there having donated.Not seen Barrow on tv since he told them about lockdown,I can see the police in the next 2 wks,adopting the big stick Indian approach as a lot are still taking no notice.
Yet another day and no cases.....https://www.facebook.com/mrcunitgambia/…
Post #74No recorded cases! How many people have been tested?

Fritwood, you should know by now that this country has few resources so testing is only going to be done on those suspected of being infected. The UK is screaming it does not have enough resources so what do you really expect of here?
Fritwood, forgot to add, if you follow the MRC link it gives an up to date count number.
5 new cases today https:/…go to Daily Diagnnostic and scroll down to the 11th

Easyltime Your post # 76So what. I was questioning the statement of "Yet another day and no cases". Not the wear with all that is going on with regards to resources. We all know how badly off for resources the Gambia is, Therefore, there is no point in making your statement of no cases.
Sorry to hear about the new cases.
Agreed post #80. Not nice to hear in a country with very little medical help.
Something strange happening - details now removed from MRC page, have messaged them and awaiting response
I just had a look and it's still saying 5 new cases.
https:/…

Well the mrc are doing the testing.

WHO figures are only as good as the reports received, I’m sure someone explained this on this forum before.MRC are doing testing....maybe no one is working at WHO to update on Easter Saturday....Edited: 4:08 pm, April 11, 2020
jeffbrum,it was a bit of a flip flop session, went up, came down and then up again. Original post correct with 5 new cases

Yes, according to the Ministry/WHO daily bulletinGambia COVID-19 StatisticLast update on: 2020-04-11 21:05:26 Global Total Cases1771546Deaths108333Recovered401473 Total in GambiaCases9Deaths1Recovered2Cases Per Million4Cases Today5Deaths Today0Critical0Active6These reports can be seen by anybody on the Ministry of Health website : Covid 19 Ministry of Health Situation Report.They are updated daily and are done in conjunction with the WHO. I expect their office peope might be having Easter weekend off which might explain why the figures differ on the WHO site.
Or if you prefer twitter -https:/…1249044040852611072
WHO are happy to accept only 3349 people have died in China, that casts serious doubt upon the accuracy of all their figures.

Bert, there are no accurate figures.In England it's mainly people who are seriously ill in hospital who are being tested. The only way work out the correct figures would be to assume the 1% mortality rate is right and put a couple of zeros on the deaths and that would depend on whether the 1% mortality rate is actually correct.Easytime, what I thought might be happening was they had taken it down because the government of Gambia hadn't announced it yet and maybe requested it be taken down until the announcement.In England there were issues about informing relatives and everything before the stats are released.
The good news, if what I've read is correct, is that they were all in quarantine, so I hope that was strict quarantine.

Of course there are no accurate figures because it is a fast developing situation, but China are taking the urine. WHO havn't even questioned their numbers despite all the mounting evidence, they just keep taking the yuan.

If you read the report it implies that 2 are currently in quarantine and the other three WERE in quarantine. IE they had previously been quarantined but weren’t when they tested positive which is rather worrying.

I don’t believe the Chinese figures either. Assuming Coronavirus “only” has a mortality rate similar to flu, in the UK it is estimated that around 5 - 10% of the population become infected and around 17000 people die as a result each year; that would mean worse case around 200000 people could die if 60% of the population ultimately caught the virus before herd immunity kicked in or a vaccine was available. We have a highly infectious, new virus, with no vaccine, that no one has immunity to unless they have already had the virus and China is suggesting only 3000 of its citizens died. Hmm.I’ve had the virus; it felt a lot worse than flu to me. The good news is that according to several studies, 50% of the people that get the virus don’t show any symptoms at all, so maybe, on average, the mortality rate will ultimately be lower than that of flu.
Please tell me where is the evidence showing that once you have had the virus you are immune and cannot get it again? I can find none.

There are currently 3 known strains of coronavirus with the B strain being the most common in the UK at present; it is highly unlikely that once you have a particular strain that you would catch that strain again -- just like flu, but unfortunately, that probably doesn't prevent you catching one or both of the other 2 strains.I think coronavirus is here to stay, just like flu. Once a working vaccine has been developed then each year vulnerable people and people willing to pay will get a combined flu and coronavirus jab containing experts' best-guess as to which strains are likely to be the most prevalent during the next season. I really hope I'm wrong and instead the virus just fades away.

Daniver, could you please tell us the source of your information as it does not seem to tally with an article in the New Scientist, I have checked that sties credibility and it is non biased and factual?https:/…

My friend here developed symptoms on Easter Monday and a crew came out within hours and she was tested. My grandson in UK also developed symptoms. No test just advice to self quarantine. Maybe we are a step ahead here

Our village pub landlord (who had an underlying health problem) came out of hospital on Tuesday after spending 10 days in the ICU unit in the John Radcliffe NHS Trust Hospital in Oxford. He is at home resting. Given that we have not heard of any more cases locally, we wonder how he got infected. He had opened up a vegetable shop to help out the community, and he employed the services of several quite young staff helpers.
I haven't read this easy time but at least it's on topic and from the horses mouth so to speak rather than the mail or the sunhttps://www.cam.ac.uk/research/news/covid-19…
Re post # 104You should read the link you provide all the way through and then read the comments. Enlightening to say the least.
What do we believe? Seems that if you have 3 researchers in room you get 4 opinions.- so who is correct?
Ahh. Opinions! Are they additions to a degree in hindsight? ;-))
The Chinese in Gambia seemed to get better hospitality than the Africans in Chinahttps:/…
Plus one:https:/…
Yep..10 today,hoping for a plane in the next 2 weeks.
Are you sure you want one?
The devil or the deep blue sea ?

The word (BBC R4 yesterday early) is that if you are listed into the 'Safeguarded' category by age and existing conditions you/we may be required to remain strictly indoors for, wait for it, one year!
This is getting ridiculous now - there ae some over 70s far fitter than the couch cowboys or fat flubbers that roam about.
I like to think so! Ha ha!

I have to agree with Easyltime.My wife and I walk approximately 5 miles every day, some times around 6. We are not talking about along flat terrain either, but over rolling countryside, and we ensure we get out of breath when going up hills. We do find that on some days we are getting sore feet.The problem with this is that we need less and less sleep and so sitting up late and watching movies on SKY and Amazon.Edited: 8:00 am, April 20, 2020

What is the latest news? Have the measures of closing the borders and stopping flights contained covid -19. It is some time since the preacher was reported to have died from it. If he had died from covid-19 I would have thought many people would be infected by now?
http://www.moh.gov.gm/covid-19-report/
Doing far better than us by the looks of it.

The reported cases in Senegal have doubled to over 600 in a day. Meanwhile the borders may be closed but not the sea routes. The fish factory at Sanyang has re opened and the beach is full of Senegalese fishing boats that have just returned.There is no social distancing bush taxis are still full to bursting and last Sunday the beach had hundreds partying. The attitude is the virus is not in gambia it will not come it is only in Europe. Allah will protect.When cv hits gambia as it surely will it will be devistating.
The latest episode of the wonderful Adeola’s show has lots of stuff about COVID in Africa https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=S2x2kHsE2cs
re 123, lost the will to live, Not sue what's worse, her voice or a dose of Covid.....Edited: 10:05 am, April 27, 2020

i had a look out of curiosity, but like easyltime, i found it difficult to tap into the in jokes.it is obviously catering for a niche market and i couldn't see the average pauline or ralph getting the humour or the message.i'll say one thing though, the video following was a thirty minute reappraisal of john jerry rawlings.now that was worth the watching, so in a way that you would never imagined, your post was not wasted, Mr. A.L.T.
Spot on Jon, when she talks it is so fast it is like listening to a machine gun. I managed to pick up about 50% of what she said.Leostaid.
Ha, you need to persevere! I think she’s great, you should check out her episodes where she ripped Jammeh to shreds a few years back.
I watched 3 and looking forward to seeing more. Her message might be obvious for someone from a different culture but may be not the case for someone like me.
Another case confirmed - now trying to trace contactsEdited: 10:31 am, May 01, 2020
And yet another case, this time in Kartong, and problems with the Military at the Checkpoint. Idiots !!!https:/…

A mass testing at Bakau Sunday? Should that fill me with fear? (Concern for family there). Is social distancing widely understood and accepted? Is it likely to be arranged for and enforced?Edited: 12:45 pm, May 02, 2020
5 new cases just confirmed https:/…

Ha ha. Funny. Actually five inches when you know that members of the same household don't have to maintain the 2M distance.I asked a question - should I be worried, in that a mass meeting if everyone is milling around waiting could prove a hot-spot for mass infection if not managed rigorously. Its the right thing to have though I still think its a worry. I was rather hoping for a reply to say worry not. And deadly serious, not flippant.
I do hope these recent posts won't be deleted on account of a technicality. It seems to happens on this forum.
My friends say this morning they are aware of the danger (their words) and will take care re distancing, masks, washing as soon as they get back home. Thanks for your info again.

People are refusing to take the tests - fear and ignorance rule here. Even expats are saying that they will not go near the test centres because they cannot guarantee social distancing despite being told it will be rigorously maintained

Your assertion by the Upper River Region man that donations of supplies by President Barrow are election bribes must refer to the sensitively-named 'dignity kits' supplied to COVID-19 cases at the treatment center ...The Gambian government's genuine response to the emergency is impressive when one imagines a small country's administrative capacity would probably be limited. Unfortunately no-one in any country quite trusts a politician though just now we have to.www.moh.gov.gm/covid-19-report/ (re 1st May download).

I strongly recommend following the updates and to become accustomed to understanding and comparing both the progress of the virus and the commendable tracing effort and follow-ups. www.moh.gov.gm/covid-19-report/ ... and today's download.My attention was to one of the last paragraphs labelled Logistics and Safety - more arrivals from Senegal. What a problem!

Can people still get the ministry of health website because I'm just getting an error message at the moment ?

Agreed - 507 Bad Gateway, and before that both Malwarebytes and BT blocked the site tonight for the first time as potential phishing risk. Admittedly not secure - http only - but as no password or transaction involved I was happy to access it. I'll try later and see if site has upgraded its credentials. MRC daily diagnostic report (click on this tab on page link below) yesterday states one new case from Bakau mass testing and one inconclusive result to be retested:https://www.mrc.gm/coronavirus-information1/Edited: 11:11 pm, May 07, 2020

http://www.moh.gov.gm/covid-19-report/Accessible again and no longer reported 'unsafe'.To my mind the most easily understood reports and interesting because of the detail - the activities undertaken daily. e.g. 'Banjul Taskforce arrested a group of 10 boys from Banjul beach who were found gambling and not adhering to the WHO guidelines on social distancing' etc etc. Two Imams arraigned etc. New positive case Senegalese fisherman entering through Sanyang etc.
2 new cases announced yesterday.
Thanks Stephen,I agree the detail is interesting.
Senegal due to be opening up from today including churches and mosques despite the fact that case numbers rise daily.Worrying development as Gambia will most likely follow their lead.

Especially worrying in view of the fact their case numbers are rising exponentially.Just today another 177 cases were confirmed.https://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/headlines/…The Senegal infection rate graph is even steeper than it was in Italy, UK or USA
Extremely worrying as there were another 177 cases today in Senegal according to the newshttps://thepoint.gm/africa/gambia/headlines/…

Krd, they've got 21 deaths and 2105 cases which looks to me like they may be doing a good job of tracking and testing unlike the UK which has 32692 deaths and 226,463 cases, which is a joke because they haven't been testing. You can't compare the rate in Senegal to the rate in the UK because the UK number has always been so fake (and I don't know about the ones in Senegal).
A new case today.https:/…Click on the daily update tab.Edited: 9:59 pm, May 22, 2020

Jeffbrum - nearly everywhere is doing better than the UK - except America, Brazil and maybe Russia. In Africa the UV light and high temperatures might be helping to reduce transmission on hard surfaces. The very low average age (19) will help to keep mortality levels down compared to European countries.For me, Senegal continues to be of concern because the borders are so porous. Yesterday a marbout was intercepted sneaking in with his 17 disciples. Reference post #189>>>I think the question is why aren’t people tested before being allowed to board the plane ?<<<It is known that many infected people do not show any symptoms for between 2 and 7 days and in some cases up to 14 days. That is why 14-day isolation is advised to people who have been in contact with known infected people. Additionally many carry the virus and are asymptomatic. That is one of the reasons that anti-body tests ( reliable or not) are being introduced in the UK. So, testing everyone who boards a plane is not going to catch every case. That is why it is not being done. My daughter (lives 40 miles away) is Health & Safety and regularly visits hospitals around Worcester to train people in many aspects. In January she was quite ill with what her doctor and she thought was influenza. There is now a doubt as to whether it was Covid-19 or influenza. She has sent in a later type test. We await the test results.

These infected people need to be identified before boarding. What about the other passengers and crew they may also have infected? I know the other passengers SHOULD be going into quarantine but from what I'm reading many don't, (I refer to those who should have gone to Badalla Park,) So they could be infecting the general population. Somebody needs to get a grip of the situation before it gets a hold there too.

Reference #Post 191 Dave F said..>>>These infected people need to be identified before boarding.<<<If they are a. asymptomatic, or b.one of the people not showing symptoms when they are infected, then they cannot be identified. That is one of the reasons that the virus spreads so easily.Edited: 10:55 am, June 28, 2020
